comment._content: What a fabulous old picture.  Thank you for sharing and making this picture available to all who are interested in things nautical.

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: It's a pleasure. I'm glad you're enjoying the photographs

comment.author: 13470978@N08
comment._content: Thanks for sharing these - they are great to see. I note a big difference in the geometry of the inboard and outboard props - is that because the shafts ran at different speeds?

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: Mauretania's trials of 1907 recorded shaft revolutions of between 123 per minute at 18.32 knots and 192 per minute at 26.17 knots with no indication that the speeds varied from shaft to shaft. However even at the trials stage Cunard and Swan Hunter & Wigham Richardson found that they were having vibration problems with Mauretania's 3 bladed propellers. These were later replaced with 4 bladed propellers. As far as I understand it all four propellers where changed and I suspect that this photograph was taken part way through the process. You can see that the two outboard propellers have 4 blades and the two inboard ones have three. If you look at the starboard inboard propeller you can see that it appears to have been nibbled! I would suggest that replacement with a 4 bladed type is imminent. However most of our reference material is concerned with the building of the ship at Wallsend so if anybody out there can suggest a different explanation I would be delighted to see it added.

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: I should mention that the response above came from our Keeper of Maritime History

comment.author: 29295370@N07
comment._content: 'Mauretania' damaged an outboard propeller by striking a submerged object in February 1909. She was drydocked for repair and the opportunity was taken to fit four bladed 'sabre' type propellers on both outboard shafts. Calculations had suggested that these propellers would increase efficiency. This duly proved to be the case and the inboard propellers were replaced at her next drydocking. Like her original outfit the 'sabre' type propellers were made by The Wallsend Slipway and Engineering Co. Ltd.

comment.author: 13470978@N08
comment._content:
Hmmm... thanks for that, although it got me a litle curious. I did a litle searching and found this [http://www.ocean-liners.com/ships/mauretania.asp]
This also leads to some photos, one of which is the stern of the vessel showing 3 bladed props on all 4 shafts. The main text indicates that the inner props were changed to 4 bladed type in 1908, but your photo contradicts that. Also, looking at your photo, those 4 blade jobs still have the writing on the blades and there is no other supports or gear around to start work on the inner ones. I suggest the outer props were changed after hitting debris (hence the chunk out of stbd inner) and this photo is taken before she left Canada dock in January 1909. Great photo, whatever the facts behind it!!
